Whenever you text them, they’ve got something happening. Friends stay- ing over, others coming to dinner. They are never not hosting.But unlike the rest of us, they don’t respond with a noncommittal “Oh, we should totally get something on the books for another night,” and then, 73 group texts later, maybe you lock down a date in six weeks’ time.Instead, their response is always the same: Just come on over. And so, more often than not, we do.This past summer, with my wife Simone away, my son Marlon and I headed out to the beach for the weekend with Simone’s cousin Tony. We rolled up to Torrey and Steven’s at 7 p.m. on a Friday, and the house was in full swing.Margarita fixings had assumed their rightful place on the kitchen counter. Marlon reached for a grapefruit sparkling water in an ice-filled cooler. A big bowl spilling over with limes, lemons, and avocados sat on the dining room table. Yes, it was more decorative than anything, but its message was clear: This house is about a good time, and you are always welcome.Brothy, beautiful clams.
Photo by Alex LauYou might assume that this all comes effortlessly to Torrey and Steven—that they simply throw together a meal with what- ever looks good at the market. They don’t. They’re like most of the readers of Bon Appétit, I imagine. They bookmark recipes from magazines and websites, they follow them to a T, they return to the ones that work, and, most important, they do all their prep work before their guests arrive.That night the house was filled with a crew of a half dozen of Torrey and Steven’s friends. It didn’t matter that none of them had met Cousin Tony before. Or who sat next to whom. Or who did what for a living. Or that Marlon spent a good 20 minutes schooling us 40-somethings on each and every dance move from Fortnite.We all settled into the evening, recognizing that we were lucky to score an invite, even if, in reality, we were crashing. Eventually, with the July sky pitch-black, we meandered out to a firepit in the backyard, plopped down into Adirondack chairs, and stared hypnotically at sparks escaping into the night. And, oh yeah, the food. It was really, really good. Torrey had made a pot of brothy, spicy clams that he ladled over slabs of charred, garlic-rubbed bread. We dug into racks of cumin-scented Sichuan-style ribs and marinated strip steaks. Also, a cooling, limey coleslaw and miso-butter corn on the cob because, vegetables.They nailed all of it. But the thing is, entertaining really isn’t about the food. We just think it is.Get the recipe:Clam Toasts with PancettaShellfish and pork are a power duo.
